Sorry, I thought we had resolved this.

IE7 handles favicons differently to every other browser (including IE6 which is different again) in fact the problem is the whole favicon things is a bit non standard.
http://www.google.co.uk/search?hl=en&source=hp&q=favicon+ie7 
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Favicon#Previous_issues_with_standardization
Which means the old way of pulling them in, basically putting an favicon.ico file at the root of your site no longer works (or rather what works for IE7 works doesn't work elsewhere and visa versa)

Marna do you mind taking a look at this one, 

I think the solution is to add two call to each page to pull the favicon in, one for IE7 and one for all other browsers ( http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Favicon#Standardization_and_implementation )
<link rel="icon" type="image/png" href="/somepath/image.png" /> (this depends on if it's a png or an ico)
<link rel="shortcut icon" href="somepath/favicon.ico" />

Will need to bulk publish the site afterwards, which is unfortunate, can I suggest we just do the home page and key sections  for now.

thanks
I want to test this on a couple of machines in the office, because I got slightly odd results with it and IE here, but think that caching is making it misbehave.
This is fixed - it'll need a republish, though, which I'll try to get going tonight.

We're investigating a workaround here, 

<brace yourself for technical reason>
The issue is the icon is assigned as part of the CSS style on the title tag, which only allows *one* background image. See attached screen shot.
So the solution isn't as easy as just adding another icon directly afterward the first one. IN fact we're still thinking of a solution that doesn't require us to dramatically change the way it currently works.
</brace yourself for technical reason>

One solution is to create individual images with more than one icon? how many cases are we talking about that need more than one venue?

just to check - you know it's NOT the sport icon that's the problem -- it's the image of the *venue*.  your screenshot show's a swimmer.  What we're interested in is the 220x120 image(s) that should be appearing in the top right column.

This is working , and up to three venues will be displayed on each sport page. Is three enough?

However, there's some inconsistency between the venue names in the metadata of the sports pages, and the names of the venue pages; if venues still aren't pulling it's probably the fault of this. 

Velodrome is specified in some of the sports pages, for example, but Velopark is the name of the page it should be matching to. Similarly, Basketball had North Greenwich Arena as its venue, but the pages are called North Greenwich Arena 1/2. I've changed that to North Greenwich Arena 1 - to check that multiple venues are being pulled in - but I've not published it yet. Is there any reason that the sports page metadata can't be amended?

There's no reason that the venue page meta data can't be amended - the
issue is that it auto-completes to those things. We just need to be
consistent! Or don't look at the name of the venue pages, look at the
metadata that the venues pages themselves have. I'll pull an accurate
list if you want....

I mentioned that we'd need http://www.london2012.com/excelconsultation to redirect to the homepage of the minisite, which now sits at http://www.london2012.com/excel/home.html .  I think this might have been set up wrong, as now when I try to type the correct full URL: http://www.london2012.com/excel/home.html i'm redirected to http://www.london2012.com/excelconsultation/home.html

Hi Finn, 

Will happily change the redirect, it's pattern matching on the first bit of the path instead of exact matching.

but out of interest why have you got an index page called home.html rather than index.html (the later will work even if the index.html bit is omitted much like the home page of the actual site or any other section)
Was blindly following the structure of the previous minisites, had wondered about that myself :-)

Hi Finn,

/excel redirects to /excelconsultation/home.html

It may take a while to publish / sync.

* leave it for now as ti works, but in future it probably makes sense to call the index page index.html (rather than home.html)
Cool, thanks Jamie

This seems to be happening again after not being a problem for a bit :-/

Reading your description above, i realise I wasn't quite paying attention at the time, but I think you have it the wrong way round perhaps?

What i'd like is that when people type http://www.london2012.com/excelconsultation, they're redirected to http://www.london2012.com/excel/home.html

Can you sort that for me and remove any other redirects that have been set up for this.  The one described above is the only one we're after.

Very odd, it looks like it got reverted back to the old version.

Have just corrected (publishing now)

Looking at why this happened, possibly Marna already had the file open and saved it after I had made my changes, checking the history now.
